current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To amend title 38, United States Code, to improve the protection and enforcement of employment and
			 reemployment rights of members of the uniformed services, and for other
			 purposes.

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

text.#text:
This Act may be cited as
			 the

header.#text:
Unenforceability
			 of agreements to arbitrate disputes arising under USERRA

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , is amended by adding at the end the following new section:

header.#text:
Unenforceability
				of agreements to arbitrate disputes

text.#text:
Notwithstanding any other provision of law, any
				clause of any agreement between an employer and an employee that
			 requires
				arbitration of a dispute arising under this chapter shall not be
				enforceable.

			 arises, the

			 dispute to
				arbitration.

			 bargaining
				agreement.

				section.

header.#text:
Expansion of

header.#text:
Suspension,
			 termination, or debarment of contractors for repeated violations of
			 employment
			 or reemployment rights of members of uniformed services

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , as amended by

, is
			 further
			 amended by adding at the end the following new section:

header.#text:
Suspension,
				termination, or debarment of contractors

text.#text:
Payment under a contract
				awarded by a Federal executive agency may be suspended and the
			 contract may be
				terminated, and the contractor who made the contract with the
			 agency may be
				suspended or debarred in accordance with the requirements of this
			 section, if
				the head of the agency determines that the contractor as an
			 employer has
				repeatedly failed or refused to comply with a provision of this
			 chapter.

header.#text:
Grounds for
				suspension, termination, or debarment

text.#text:
A contracting
				officer who determines in writing that cause for suspension of
			 payments,
				termination, or suspension or debarment exists shall initiate an
			 appropriate
				action, to be conducted by the agency concerned in accordance with
			 applicable
				law, including Executive Order 12549 or any superseding Executive
			 order, the
				Federal Acquisition Regulation, and any other regulations
			 prescribed to
				implement the law or Executive order.

header.#text:
Conduct of
				suspension, termination, and debarment proceedings

text.#text:
A contractor debarred by a final decision under this
				section is ineligible for award of a contract by a Federal
			 executive agency,
				and for participation in a future procurement by a Federal
			 executive agency,
				for a period specified in the decision, not to exceed 5
				years.
